content: Wash your belly button whenever you shower. The best time to clean your belly button is during a regular bath or shower. Make an effort to include your belly button in your daily washing routine. [1] You may need to wash your belly button more frequently if you’ve been sweating a lot (e.g., after exercise or when the weather is hot). Use plain soap and water for routine washing. You don’t need anything fancy to wash your navel. Warm water and gentle soap will do the trick just fine! Apply some soap and water to your fingers or a washcloth and gently rub it into your belly button to get rid of dirt, grime, and lint . When you’re done, carefully rinse away all the suds. [2] Use a gentle, unscented soap or bodywash if scented soaps cause drying or irritation. You can also use saltwater to gently cleanse your belly button. Mix 1 teaspoon (about 6 g) of table salt with 1 cup (240 mL) of warm water and dip a washcloth in the solution. Carefully massage the saltwater into your navel, then rinse it away with plain water. [4] Saltwater can kill germs and loosen dirt, and you may find it less drying and irritating than soap. Deep-clean an innie with a washcloth or cotton swab. It’s easy for dirt and lint to build up in a deep belly button—and it can be challenging to get it out! If you have an innie, you may need to use a washcloth or a cotton swab to get inside and do a thorough cleaning. [5] Swab out the inside of your belly button gently with soap and water, and make sure to rinse it well afterward. Don’t scrub hard—you could irritate the delicate skin in and around your belly button. Pat your belly button dry when you’re done. It’s important to keep your belly button dry to prevent an overgrowth of bacteria and fungus. Once you’re done washing up, use a clean, dry towel to gently dry the area in and around your belly button. If you have time, you can also let it air-dry for a few minutes before putting on clothing. [6] You can keep moisture from building up in your belly button during the day by dressing in cool, loose clothing. Avoid using oils, creams, or lotions in your belly button. Don’t use any creams or lotions in your belly button unless your doctor recommends it. Doing so could trap moisture inside your belly button, creating a good environment for unwanted bacteria, fungus, or yeast. [7] You may be able to safely moisturize your belly button with a little baby oil or light moisturizing lotion if you have an outie, however. [8] Look for signs of infection if regular washing doesn’t work. The most common cause for unpleasant belly button odors is dirt and sweat. In most cases, washing up with a little soap and water will clear up any unwanted smells. If it doesn’t, you might have an infection. Look for symptoms such as: [9] Scaly red skin Tenderness or swelling in or around your belly button Itching Yellow or green fluid or pus leaking from your belly button Fever or general feelings of illness or fatigue See your doctor for a diagnosis if you have infection symptoms. If you think you have an infection, make an appointment with your doctor right away. They can evaluate what kind of infection you have and tell you how to treat it properly . [10] The appropriate treatment will be different depending on whether your infection is caused by bacteria, fungus, or yeast. Don’t try to guess what kind of infection you have, since using the wrong treatment could do more harm than good. Your doctor may swab your belly button to get a sample for testing. This can help them determine what’s causing your infection. Use topical medications to treat a bacterial, fungal, or yeast infection. If it turns out you have an infection in your belly button, you may need to use an antibiotic or antifungal ointment or powder for a while to clear it up. Your doctor may prescribe a medication or instruct you to buy one over-the-counter. Treating the infection should also get rid of any nasty odors or discharge! [11] Follow any other home care instructions your doctor may have, such as: Resisting the urge to scratch or pick at your infected belly button Changing and washing your bedsheets and clothing regularly to prevent reinfection Avoiding sharing towels with other people Wearing loose, comfortable clothing to help keep your belly button cool and dry Cleansing your belly button daily with a saltwater solution Ask your doctor to drain a belly button cyst if you have one. Sometimes a cyst can form in your belly button, potentially leading to swelling, pain, and bad-smelling discharge. If you have an infected cyst in your belly button, your doctor will probably drain the cyst in their office. They may also prescribe antibiotics to help clear up the infection. Follow their home care instructions to help the cyst heal properly. [12] If the cyst comes back, you may need to have surgery to remove it completely. Ask your doctor for detailed instructions on how to clean and care for your cyst at home. Visit your doctor to get navel stones removed if necessary. If you have a deep belly button and don’t clean it often enough, dirt, lint, and oils can build up inside it. Eventually, these materials can form a hardened mass, called an omphalith or navel stone. [13] If this happens to you, make an appointment with your doctor. They can use forceps to gently pull out the stone. In many cases, navel stones don’t cause any symptoms. Sometimes, however, they can cause sores and infections to develop. You can prevent navel stones by cleaning your belly button regularly with soap and water.

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Your-Belly-Button">How to Clean Your Belly Button</a></h1>
<div class="" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="staff_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		wikiHow Staff</a><span class="ss_pipe">|</span><a class="expert_coauthor_link ss_review" href="#article_info_section">Reader-Approved</a>
<span class="ss_pipe">|</span><a href="#references">14 References</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Creating_a_Regular_Cleansing_Routine_sub" id="">Creating a Regular Cleansing Routine</a>

</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">

		<a class="sp_learn_more_link" href="/wikiHow:About-wikiHow#Why_should_you_choose_wikiHow_first.3F_sub">Learn more...</a>

</div>
<p>Your belly button is easy to overlook, but it needs to be cleaned just like every other part of your body. Fortunately, all it takes to keep your belly button clean is a little soap and water! If you have unpleasant belly button odor that doesn’t go away with regular washing, check for signs of an infection. With proper medical treatment, you can clear up the source of the odor and get back to smelling fresh and clean.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Creating_a_Regular_Cleansing_Routine_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Creating_a_Regular_Cleansing_Routine">Creating a Regular Cleansing Routine</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Wash your belly button whenever you shower.</b> The best time to clean your belly button is during a regular bath or shower. Make an effort to include your belly button in your daily washing routine.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup><ul>
<li>You may need to wash your belly button more frequently if you’ve been sweating a lot (e.g., after exercise or when the weather is hot).</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use plain soap and water for routine washing.</b> You don’t need anything fancy to wash your navel. Warm water and gentle soap will do the trick just fine! Apply some soap and water to your fingers or a washcloth and gently rub it into your belly button to get rid of dirt, grime, and <a href="/Clean-Belly-Button-Lint" title="Clean Belly Button Lint">lint</a>. When you’re done, carefully rinse away all the suds.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Use a gentle, unscented soap or bodywash if scented soaps cause drying or irritation.</li>
<li>You can also use saltwater to gently cleanse your belly button. Mix 1 teaspoon (about 6 g) of table salt with 1 cup (240 mL) of warm water and dip a washcloth in the solution. Carefully massage the saltwater into your navel, then rinse it away with plain water.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Saltwater can kill germs and loosen dirt, and you may find it less drying and irritating than soap.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="green_box">
<p><b>Tip:</b> If your belly button is pierced, you’ll need to take special care to <a href="/Keep-Your-Navel-Piercing-Clean" title="Keep Your Navel Piercing Clean">keep it clean</a>. Use a warm saltwater solution to clean the area around the piercing at least 2-3 times a day, or as often as your piercing artist or doctor recommends.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup></p>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Clean-Your-Belly-Button-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=122895" href="#/Image:Clean-Your-Belly-Button-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Clean Your Belly Button Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Clean-Your-Belly-Button-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid122895-v4-728px-Clean-Your-Belly-Button-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c2ed0f15ea" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c2ed0f15ea')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Clean Your Belly Button Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Clean-Your-Belly-Button-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid122895-v4-728px-Clean-Your-Belly-Button-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Deep-clean an innie with a washcloth or cotton swab.</b> It’s easy for dirt and lint to build up in a deep belly button—and it can be challenging to get it out! If you have an innie, you may need to use a washcloth or a cotton swab to get inside and do a thorough cleaning.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup> Swab out the inside of your belly button gently with soap and water, and make sure to rinse it well afterward.

<ul>
<li>Don’t scrub hard—you could irritate the delicate skin in and around your belly button.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Pat your belly button dry when you’re done.</b> It’s important to keep your belly button dry to prevent an overgrowth of bacteria and fungus. Once you’re done washing up, use a clean, dry towel to gently dry the area in and around your belly button. If you have time, you can also let it air-dry for a few minutes before putting on clothing.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup><ul>
<li>You can keep moisture from building up in your belly button during the day by dressing in cool, loose clothing.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Avoid using oils, creams, or lotions in your belly button.</b> Don’t use any creams or lotions in your belly button unless your doctor recommends it. Doing so could trap moisture inside your belly button, creating a good environment for unwanted bacteria, fungus, or yeast.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup><ul>
<li>You may be able to safely moisturize your belly button with a little baby oil or light moisturizing lotion if you have an outie, however.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Dealing_with_Belly_Button_Odors_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Dealing_with_Belly_Button_Odors">Dealing with Belly Button Odors</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Look for signs of infection if regular washing doesn’t work.</b> The most common cause for unpleasant belly button odors is dirt and sweat. In most cases, washing up with a little soap and water will clear up any unwanted smells. If it doesn’t, you might have an infection. Look for symptoms such as:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Scaly red skin</li>
<li>Tenderness or swelling in or around your belly button</li>
<li>Itching</li>
<li>Yellow or green fluid or pus leaking from your belly button</li>
<li>Fever or general feelings of illness or fatigue</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="green_box">
<p><b>Warning:</b> Infections are more likely if you have a belly button piercing. If you have a piercing, look out for signs of infection such as increasing pain or tenderness, swelling, redness, warmth around the piercing, or pus.</p>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">See your doctor for a diagnosis if you have infection symptoms.</b> If you think you have an infection, make an appointment with your doctor right away. They can evaluate what kind of infection you have and tell you how to <a href="/Treat-an-Infection-in-Your-Belly-Button" title="Treat an Infection in Your Belly Button">treat it properly</a>.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup><ul>
<li>The appropriate treatment will be different depending on whether your infection is caused by bacteria, fungus, or yeast. Don’t try to guess what kind of infection you have, since using the wrong treatment could do more harm than good.</li>
<li>Your doctor may swab your belly button to get a sample for testing. This can help them determine what’s causing your infection.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use topical medications to treat a bacterial, fungal, or yeast infection.</b> If it turns out you have an infection in your belly button, you may need to use an antibiotic or antifungal ointment or powder for a while to clear it up. Your doctor may prescribe a medication or instruct you to buy one over-the-counter. Treating the infection should also get rid of any nasty odors or discharge!<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup> Follow any other home care instructions your doctor may have, such as:
<ul>
<li>Resisting the urge to scratch or pick at your infected belly button</li>
<li>Changing and washing your bedsheets and clothing regularly to prevent reinfection</li>
<li>Avoiding sharing towels with other people</li>
<li>Wearing loose, comfortable clothing to help keep your belly button cool and dry</li>
<li>Cleansing your belly button daily with a saltwater solution</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ask your doctor to drain a belly button cyst if you have one.</b> Sometimes a cyst can form in your belly button, potentially leading to swelling, pain, and bad-smelling discharge. If you have an infected cyst in your belly button, your doctor will probably drain the cyst in their office. They may also prescribe antibiotics to help clear up the infection. Follow their home care instructions to help the cyst heal properly.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup><ul>
<li>If the cyst comes back, you may need to have surgery to remove it completely.</li>
<li>Ask your doctor for detailed instructions on how to clean and care for your cyst at home.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="final_li">
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Visit your doctor to get navel stones removed if necessary.</b> If you have a deep belly button and don’t clean it often enough, dirt, lint, and oils can build up inside it. Eventually, these materials can form a hardened mass, called an omphalith or navel stone.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup> If this happens to you, make an appointment with your doctor. They can use forceps to gently pull out the stone.
<ul>
<li>In many cases, navel stones don’t cause any symptoms. Sometimes, however, they can cause sores and infections to develop.</li>
<li>You can prevent navel stones by cleaning your belly button regularly with soap and water.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

</li>
</ol>

</div>

<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="122895" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>

<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="567068" data-caid="567941" data-cqid="567085" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2860555" data-submitter_id="4142224" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="0">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Does it hurt when you clean your belly button?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/skins/WikiHow/wH-initials_152x152.png)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">wikiHow Staff Editor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Staff Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Some people have very sensitive navels, so it's possible you might feel some pain or discomfort if you don't handle your belly button gently. If you're sensitive, avoid scrubbing your belly button and just gently massage it with soap and water or a saltwater solution. </div>

</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="567066" data-caid="567939" data-cqid="567083" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2867098" data-submitter_id="4142224" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="0">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I not clean my belly button with a spirit?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/skins/WikiHow/wH-initials_152x152.png)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">wikiHow Staff Editor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Staff Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">In general, it's best to clean your belly button with plain soap and water or a mild saltwater solution. While some doctors recommend using rubbing alcohol, it's usually not necessary (and you definitely shouldn't do it if it causes irritation or over-drying). </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="567071" data-caid="567944" data-cqid="567088" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2788176" data-submitter_id="4142224" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="0">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">My belly button is always leaking clear fluid, and I am forced to clean it many times daily. What may this be?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/skins/WikiHow/wH-initials_152x152.png)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">wikiHow Staff Editor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Staff Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Any kind of discharge from your belly button could be a sign of infection. Make an appointment with your doctor to have it looked at. They can identify the cause and help you treat it appropriately. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<div class="qa_q_txt question">What happens if navel stones form? </div>

<div class="qa_user_label">Staff Answer</div>
</div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">It's best to have a doctor remove the navel stones for you. To prevent them from forming, clean your belly button regularly and check it occasionally (e.g., once a week) to make sure lint and dirt aren't building up inside. </div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">The best way to clean your belly button is with warm water and mild soap. A saltwater solution can also work well. <div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>If you tend to get lint in your belly button, you can minimize it by wearing newer clothes and trimming or shaving any hair that grows close to your navel.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Newborn babies need special care for their belly buttons, especially right after the <a href="/Clean-an-Umbilical-Cord-Stump-on-a-Newborn-Baby" title="Clean an Umbilical Cord Stump on a Newborn Baby">umbilical cord stump</a> falls off. If you have a baby, talk to your pediatrician about the best way to clean and care for their belly button.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>If you suspect you have an infected navel piercing, make an appointment with your doctor right away to get appropriate treatment.</li>
<li>Never try to clean or remove lint from your belly button with a sharp object, such as a pair of tweezers or a metal manicure tool, since you could injure yourself. Always use your fingers or a clean cloth or cotton swab.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To clean your belly button, use your finger or a washcloth to rub some warm, soapy water into it, which will get rid of any dirt, grime, and lint. Alternatively, you can stir 1 teaspoon of salt into a cup of water and use that to clean your belly button, since saltwater also kills germs and can be less irritating than soap. Either way, make sure you pat your belly button dry when you're finished to prevent bacteria from growing in it. Generally, you should aim to clean your belly button whenever you shower, but you might want to clean it more if you've been sweating a lot. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For tips on how to deal with belly button odors, scroll down!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Creating a Regular Cleansing Routine",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Wash your belly button whenever you shower. The best time to clean your belly button is during a regular bath or shower. Make an effort to include your belly button in your daily washing routine.[1]You may need to wash your belly button more frequently if you\u2019ve been sweating a lot (e.g., after exercise or when the weather is hot)."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use plain soap and water for routine washing. You don\u2019t need anything fancy to wash your navel. Warm water and gentle soap will do the trick just fine! Apply some soap and water to your fingers or a washcloth and gently rub it into your belly button to get rid of dirt, grime, and lint. When you\u2019re done, carefully rinse away all the suds.[2]\nTip: If your belly button is pierced, you\u2019ll need to take special care to keep it clean. Use a warm saltwater solution to clean the area around the piercing at least 2-3 times a day, or as often as your piercing artist or doctor recommends.[3]\n\nUse a gentle, unscented soap or bodywash if scented soaps cause drying or irritation.\nYou can also use saltwater to gently cleanse your belly button. Mix 1 teaspoon (about 6 g) of table salt with 1 cup (240\u00a0mL) of warm water and dip a washcloth in the solution. Carefully massage the saltwater into your navel, then rinse it away with plain water.[4]\nSaltwater can kill germs and loosen dirt, and you may find it less drying and irritating than soap."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Deep-clean an innie with a washcloth or cotton swab. It\u2019s easy for dirt and lint to build up in a deep belly button\u2014and it can be challenging to get it out! If you have an innie, you may need to use a washcloth or a cotton swab to get inside and do a thorough cleaning.[5] Swab out the inside of your belly button gently with soap and water, and make sure to rinse it well afterward.\n\nDon\u2019t scrub hard\u2014you could irritate the delicate skin in and around your belly button."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Pat your belly button dry when you\u2019re done. It\u2019s important to keep your belly button dry to prevent an overgrowth of bacteria and fungus. Once you\u2019re done washing up, use a clean, dry towel to gently dry the area in and around your belly button. If you have time, you can also let it air-dry for a few minutes before putting on clothing.[6]You can keep moisture from building up in your belly button during the day by dressing in cool, loose clothing."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Avoid using oils, creams, or lotions in your belly button. Don\u2019t use any creams or lotions in your belly button unless your doctor recommends it. Doing so could trap moisture inside your belly button, creating a good environment for unwanted bacteria, fungus, or yeast.[7]You may be able to safely moisturize your belly button with a little baby oil or light moisturizing lotion if you have an outie, however.[8]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Dealing with Belly Button Odors",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Look for signs of infection if regular washing doesn\u2019t work. The most common cause for unpleasant belly button odors is dirt and sweat. In most cases, washing up with a little soap and water will clear up any unwanted smells. If it doesn\u2019t, you might have an infection. Look for symptoms such as:[9]\nWarning: Infections are more likely if you have a belly button piercing. If you have a piercing, look out for signs of infection such as increasing pain or tenderness, swelling, redness, warmth around the piercing, or pus.\n\nScaly red skin\nTenderness or swelling in or around your belly button\nItching\nYellow or green fluid or pus leaking from your belly button\nFever or general feelings of illness or fatigue"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "See your doctor for a diagnosis if you have infection symptoms. If you think you have an infection, make an appointment with your doctor right away. They can evaluate what kind of infection you have and tell you how to treat it properly.[10]The appropriate treatment will be different depending on whether your infection is caused by bacteria, fungus, or yeast. Don\u2019t try to guess what kind of infection you have, since using the wrong treatment could do more harm than good.\nYour doctor may swab your belly button to get a sample for testing. This can help them determine what\u2019s causing your infection."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use topical medications to treat a bacterial, fungal, or yeast infection. If it turns out you have an infection in your belly button, you may need to use an antibiotic or antifungal ointment or powder for a while to clear it up. Your doctor may prescribe a medication or instruct you to buy one over-the-counter. Treating the infection should also get rid of any nasty odors or discharge![11] Follow any other home care instructions your doctor may have, such as:\nResisting the urge to scratch or pick at your infected belly button\nChanging and washing your bedsheets and clothing regularly to prevent reinfection\nAvoiding sharing towels with other people\nWearing loose, comfortable clothing to help keep your belly button cool and dry\nCleansing your belly button daily with a saltwater solution"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Ask your doctor to drain a belly button cyst if you have one. Sometimes a cyst can form in your belly button, potentially leading to swelling, pain, and bad-smelling discharge. If you have an infected cyst in your belly button, your doctor will probably drain the cyst in their office. They may also prescribe antibiotics to help clear up the infection. Follow their home care instructions to help the cyst heal properly.[12]If the cyst comes back, you may need to have surgery to remove it completely.\nAsk your doctor for detailed instructions on how to clean and care for your cyst at home."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Visit your doctor to get navel stones removed if necessary. If you have a deep belly button and don\u2019t clean it often enough, dirt, lint, and oils can build up inside it. Eventually, these materials can form a hardened mass, called an omphalith or navel stone.[13] If this happens to you, make an appointment with your doctor. They can use forceps to gently pull out the stone.\nIn many cases, navel stones don\u2019t cause any symptoms. Sometimes, however, they can cause sores and infections to develop.\nYou can prevent navel stones by cleaning your belly button regularly with soap and water."
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],

title: How to Clean Your Belly Button
content_html:
Wash your belly button whenever you shower. The best time to clean your belly button is during a regular bath or shower. Make an effort to include your belly button in your daily washing routine.[1]
  • You may need to wash your belly button more frequently if you’ve been sweating a lot (e.g., after exercise or when the weather is hot).
Use plain soap and water for routine washing. You don’t need anything fancy to wash your navel. Warm water and gentle soap will do the trick just fine! Apply some soap and water to your fingers or a washcloth and gently rub it into your belly button to get rid of dirt, grime, and lint. When you’re done, carefully rinse away all the suds.[2]
  • Use a gentle, unscented soap or bodywash if scented soaps cause drying or irritation.
  • You can also use saltwater to gently cleanse your belly button. Mix 1 teaspoon (about 6 g) of table salt with 1 cup (240 mL) of warm water and dip a washcloth in the solution. Carefully massage the saltwater into your navel, then rinse it away with plain water.[4]
  • Saltwater can kill germs and loosen dirt, and you may find it less drying and irritating than soap.
Deep-clean an innie with a washcloth or cotton swab. It’s easy for dirt and lint to build up in a deep belly button—and it can be challenging to get it out! If you have an innie, you may need to use a washcloth or a cotton swab to get inside and do a thorough cleaning.[5] Swab out the inside of your belly button gently with soap and water, and make sure to rinse it well afterward.
  • Don’t scrub hard—you could irritate the delicate skin in and around your belly button.
Pat your belly button dry when you’re done. It’s important to keep your belly button dry to prevent an overgrowth of bacteria and fungus. Once you’re done washing up, use a clean, dry towel to gently dry the area in and around your belly button. If you have time, you can also let it air-dry for a few minutes before putting on clothing.[6]
  • You can keep moisture from building up in your belly button during the day by dressing in cool, loose clothing.
Avoid using oils, creams, or lotions in your belly button. Don’t use any creams or lotions in your belly button unless your doctor recommends it. Doing so could trap moisture inside your belly button, creating a good environment for unwanted bacteria, fungus, or yeast.[7]
  • You may be able to safely moisturize your belly button with a little baby oil or light moisturizing lotion if you have an outie, however.[8]
Look for signs of infection if regular washing doesn’t work. The most common cause for unpleasant belly button odors is dirt and sweat. In most cases, washing up with a little soap and water will clear up any unwanted smells. If it doesn’t, you might have an infection. Look for symptoms such as:[9]
  • Scaly red skin
  • Tenderness or swelling in or around your belly button
  • Itching
  • Yellow or green fluid or pus leaking from your belly button
  • Fever or general feelings of illness or fatigue
See your doctor for a diagnosis if you have infection symptoms. If you think you have an infection, make an appointment with your doctor right away. They can evaluate what kind of infection you have and tell you how to treat it properly.[10]
  • The appropriate treatment will be different depending on whether your infection is caused by bacteria, fungus, or yeast. Don’t try to guess what kind of infection you have, since using the wrong treatment could do more harm than good.
  • Your doctor may swab your belly button to get a sample for testing. This can help them determine what’s causing your infection.
Use topical medications to treat a bacterial, fungal, or yeast infection. If it turns out you have an infection in your belly button, you may need to use an antibiotic or antifungal ointment or powder for a while to clear it up. Your doctor may prescribe a medication or instruct you to buy one over-the-counter. Treating the infection should also get rid of any nasty odors or discharge![11] Follow any other home care instructions your doctor may have, such as:
  • Resisting the urge to scratch or pick at your infected belly button
  • Changing and washing your bedsheets and clothing regularly to prevent reinfection
  • Avoiding sharing towels with other people
  • Wearing loose, comfortable clothing to help keep your belly button cool and dry
  • Cleansing your belly button daily with a saltwater solution
Ask your doctor to drain a belly button cyst if you have one. Sometimes a cyst can form in your belly button, potentially leading to swelling, pain, and bad-smelling discharge. If you have an infected cyst in your belly button, your doctor will probably drain the cyst in their office. They may also prescribe antibiotics to help clear up the infection. Follow their home care instructions to help the cyst heal properly.[12]
  • If the cyst comes back, you may need to have surgery to remove it completely.
  • Ask your doctor for detailed instructions on how to clean and care for your cyst at home.
Visit your doctor to get navel stones removed if necessary. If you have a deep belly button and don’t clean it often enough, dirt, lint, and oils can build up inside it. Eventually, these materials can form a hardened mass, called an omphalith or navel stone.[13] If this happens to you, make an appointment with your doctor. They can use forceps to gently pull out the stone.
  • In many cases, navel stones don’t cause any symptoms. Sometimes, however, they can cause sores and infections to develop.
  • You can prevent navel stones by cleaning your belly button regularly with soap and water.
